And under the rational of the Second Circuit where due process is measured only by the loss experience by the inmate and I think legally we would be required to give hearings in this situation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Under the prison rules or do the prison rules expressly say that for certain kinds of conduct a transfer is inappropriate sanction?

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: No, they don't as a matter of fact the Court of Appeals struck out that requirement in the District Court's order because the Court of Appeals believed that it would be impossible to specify all of these situations that might lead to a transfer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, Justice White's question was about the prison rule it's not about the District Court judgment.

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: No, there's nothing in the prison rules.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Were there or was there ever?

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: No, there was none.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you didn't have prison rules as to defining what kind of sanctions would be imposed for certain kinds of conduct?

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: We have departmental regulations which list we have adjustment committee hearings and we have formal disciplinary hearings and they listed these positions that an inmate can receive as a result of those hearings.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, does that suggest that transfer is not a type of punishment under the rules?

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: Well, the rules do provide for a program change that could be interpreted as a transfer but the department's policy is not to use transfers as --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you told me that before.

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But again, the rules purport to say if you would engage in certain of kind of conduct here's what might happen to you and the rules don't say that a transfer is imposed for engaging in those kinds of conduct.

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: That is correct.
Yes, they do not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: For once, I am still surprise you don't just say that there isn't any such thing as disciplinary transfer prisons in New York.

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: Well, we did --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: About these transfers they just are not for discipline.

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: We did say that but the Court of Appeals very flatly rejected that assertion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I thought you while ago said, “Yes, there are disciplinary transfers.”

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I'm trying to get away from them but you said there are some.

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: No, I said it was conceivable that if you interpret a program change is a transfer to another institution, there could be one but in that case, the man would have to be given formal notice of charges.
But in practice, no, we don't have disciplinary transfers and in that respect, we differ for I believe from the federal system.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Hoffman, --

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- in New York when a judge sentenced a convicted person does he designate the prison to which he shall be sent?

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: No, he is -- unless, it's a special case for example a juvenile offend or where he might go to reformatory but other than that he's merely remanded to the Department of Corrections.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the Department of Corrections makes a judgment as to where he should be confined?

turn.speaker: hillel_hoffman
turn.label: Mr. Hillel Hoffman
turn.text: That is correct.
The judgment is made to the classification and intake center, and even in that process a man may go back and forth between institutions.

For example a man may be received at Green Haven and be sent to Sing Sing for a month for classification and then go back to Green Haven or go to Clinton, or go to Attica and all of these institutions do have some differences and that's what we're concerned about here, that if the measure of due process is the loss of privileges or the distance from the place of conviction, then the possibilities of hearings are endless in these cases.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
